author: Admirable_Nothing
body:
It is hard to tell what tech stocks and the NASDAQ will do but a bit of history is worth studying.

In 2000 Cisco was the giant of the internet and the internet was the giant of tech stocks. Every employee at Cisco was rich because they all got stock options (yes, including the janitors in those days) and the stock price had climbed from $10 in 98 to $33 in 99 and $79/sh in 2000. They did then sell and still do sell routers that were the backbone of the internet and CSCO was everyone's tech darling. I can't tell you how many Cisco employees had told me in spring of 2000 that they were not going to diversify until CSCO hit $100/sh. In Sept of 2001, their share price had dropped to $12/share. They still were the backbone of the internet but the internet and tech were no longer the darling of the Market. In Feb of 2009 they were at $14/sh and are today at $48/sh. So they today as an ongoing company still doing what it did and with a strong balance sheet are trading at roughly 2/3rds the price they were 20 years ago. That is what can happen to a really good tech company.

BTW, CSCO is not the only one. Intel was at $74.88 in the fall of 2000 and is at $60/sh now and was running around in the $20's for most of the past 20 years. Still a great tech company doing great things.   And yes Intel employees also got rich on options.  I met with a Intel employee, a janitor, single, living in a trailer that was about to exercise $3 mm in net in the money INTC options and needed help with estate planning.   Those were the days.  A short edit:  In 2000 the estate tax began with only $675,000 of assets at death and it started just below 50% and quickly grew to 55%.   So you didn't need to be very wealthy to need estate tax planning.

Microsoft, one of today's tech darlings, was $50/sh in early 2000. It wandered around $25/share for 15 years until it again hit $50/sh in fall of 2015, fifteen long years later. The last 5 years have been good for it but will it stay at $200/sh?

author: likeitis121
body:
Depends on how you categorize them.  They aren't software companies, but the general market sees them as tech companies, which is the companies that benefit so much.  The people hyping up Tesla so much, are arguing that it's a tech company, even though it makes cars.

The big 5 (MSFT/AAPL/AMZN/FB/GOOG) are definitely solid companies.  That doesn't change the fact that they've gotten overvalued.  Apple has grown 2.5x in value the past few years, but revenues have slowed, and profits really haven't changed much.  

Below that top tier you have a bunch of unprofitable $100-300M companies that have gotten hyped up.  And simply comparing it to 2000 without reference is ignoring it.  Microsoft, Cisco, and Intel were top 10 companies and weren't the single product late 90's product that you focus on.  Cisco still lost 90% of it's value, and still isn't back up there.  Microsoft still took 16 years to recover it's lost market cap.  

How am I throwing a tantrum.  It's a fact that the only time that valuation compared to trailing earnings was higher was the dot com bubble, and near right before great depression, the only time that market cap was higher as a percentage of GDP was dot com bubble.  There's tons of comparables that suggest this market is overvalued, and absolutely 0 that it's undervalued compared to history.

author: skwirly715
body:
MSFT has growth potential due to its diversification across tech sub-sectors. It is also safe for this reason, whereas single-service companies are less so. I don’t think you can put it in the same box as Cisco or Intel, hardware companies focused on providing a single service. 

MSFT has greater market share in the broader tech sector than either of those companies because it has expanded vertically (across sub sectors, for example gaming, office software, web services, laptops/hardware) instead of trying to expand horizontally (within its own sub sector) and has plans to continue to do so via its cloud services. I personally do not know who will “win” the cloud web services sub sector but I know that MSFT won’t lose purely due to its advantage in existing office software (MS Office integrates well with devices like Azure and Sharepoint making it more appealing to companies exploring the cloud).

I love your take regarding the cyclical nature of those speculator dollars, but I think MSFT should be compared to AAPL, AMZN, and GOOG instead of CSCO and Intel. Maybe Shopify is a better comp for CSCO and Intel?

author: Iskippedfaceday
body:
I don’t mean to sound rebellious, but this sub has really rejected the potential of this stock for no reason.

They are partnered with: Apple, Nvidia, Intel, AMD, Boeing, IBM, Lenovo, HP, Lyft, Puma, Toshiba, Raytheon, Thunderbolt, Universal Audio, Focusrite, and Cisco etc...

They also make twice as much revenue as their entire market cap and now have the only PCIe 4.0 expansion system in the world.

I understand that the history of this sub is based on people getting burned and such, but when we all drool over a possible partnership with ONE of those companies? This company has them all already. 

Their contracts with the U.S. military, side projects with NVIDIA, and the incentives given to their CEO to keep their share price up are just bonuses. 

I am really committed to seeing how this company performs, because after beating their earnings so many times, they are definitely well-positioned to move forward.

author: Admirable_Nothing
body: Dividends?  We are talking about tech stocks here.  CSCO began dividends in 2011 at an overwhelming $0.06/share.  MSFT started dividends in 2003 at a magnificent 8 cents/share and today is paying an outstanding dividend of 0.98%.   Intel (INTC) was paying dividends in 2000 and it was a huge 2 cents/share.   The words dividends and tech stocks can not easily be used in the same sentence.

author: Admirable_Nothing
body:
I seriously thought about buying a Model 3 last year.  Ultimately I did not as I think I would have range anxiety on long trips.  But a number of friends have Teslas and each of them really like the car.  I also think that Tesla is going to be a viable car company long term and will do well in the future.

The problem is that the current price would only be justified if they were already profitable building and selling 5-6 mm cars per year and they don't do 10% of that and are not in any way profitable.   So anyone buying now is assuming they will find somebody that is a greater fool than they are to actually buy the stock from them at a price higher than $1500.

In 2000 I was young and stupid and financially had a great year.  Some of the companies I invested in that are still very successful and still leaders in their field were CSCO and JNPR.   2000 was the year of the internet and Cisco built all the routers for the internet worldwide.  Some ex Cisco employees had started Juniper and were building specialty routers that were pushing Cisco to improve.   All of that still is true and both companies are fabulously profitable and leaders in their field but today can be classified as old tech.  I paid $65/sh for CSCO and bought JNPR at $65, $83, and $115/sh.   Today CSCO is $48 and JNPR is $22 with no splits in the meantime.   Sometime you can be early and never recover.   That is where Tesla is now.   In 20 years 80% of the cars being sold will be EVs or H2 and every manufacturer will be making excellent products.  Tesla will be old tech and the 20 year olds now pumping Tesla will be 40 with 2 kids approaching college age and wondering about that $1500/sh stock they bought in 2020 that is worth $350/sh in 2040.

author: __justsayin__
body: You don't want a tech stock paying a "good dividend" since most of them are losers - just look at the likes of IBM, CSCO, even QCOM.  You want a tech company which focuses on growth, and growth companies typically do not pay dividends.

author: CptTonyStark
body:
NASDAQ more than tripled from late 1998 to March 2000. The P/E ratios soared above 100. Expectations of future stock returns ranged from 15%-25% a year. 

CISCO was selling at a triple digit P/E ratio, with a market cap of $600 billion. If Cisco grew it's earnings by 15% a year, it would still be selling well above the avg P/E ratio 10 years later. And if it returned 15% for the next 25 years and the US economy continued growing at 5% a year, Cisco would be bigger than the entire economy.

When the bubble burst, even a blue Chip like Cisco lost 90% of its value.

author: _icarcus
body:
first, figure out which sector you want to invest in. tech? energy? cloud computing? AI? home builders? 

second, find ETF’s that cover that sector and then compare its 5-10 yr chart to the S&P 500. 

From an outside perspective, from Jim Cramer — host of CNBC’s, MAD MONEY — a fool proof way to start a saving is to invest your first $10,000 into a total market ETFs. Something like the SPY, VOO, VTI, or — if you want to focus on growth stocks — high risk, high return: VOOG. 

Overall, ETFs will allow you exposure to hundreds of companies under one name. Apple, MSFT, Cisco will all be  a tech focused ETF. They, on average, follow the markets trend and produce steady but OK returns. 

Check out etf.com and look at their ETF screeners. They’ll tell you the expense rates (how much it costs a year), it’s price, what companies it has holdings in, and it has a return chart of 5+ years.

author: AccomplishedClub6
body:
You are assuming GE and CSCO aren't also part of index funds that people have invested in (which also lost money when these stocks dropped).

You are also assuming 100% of the stocks people pick will crash down and never recover, and there won't be big winners in some of their picks.  Picking stocks is exactly like an index fund, except it's a smaller group of stocks relative to the thousands in an index fund.  So just like an index fund, there will be losers in your stock picks.  But just like an index, there will be 20% of your picks that return 80% of the total profits over the long term.

author: NerdBlender
body:
I’m sorry, but how exactly do they have a back door? 

You obviously don’t understand how networks work. It’s absolutely no more risk using Huawei than using Cisco, Nokia, Ericsson or anyone else.

Network providers build security around devices and can see exactly how much data is being sent where, if a copy of data was being funnelled to China, or if someone was attempting unauthorised access to equipment you would be damn sure they would know about it.

If we were saying we are not using Huawei because of China and their human rights records or their censorship, then fine. But we are doing this because the US say so. 

I have never seen a scrap of evidence that says Huawei are any less secure than any other network hardware vendor. If there was, don’t you think their competition and the security services would be shouting it from the rooftops, but they are not. 

This is not a national security issue, this is a trade issue.

author: MementoMori97
body:
My advice:

1) Index funds are a great way to mitigate some risk from just holding singular companies. Personally I hold my entire Roth in mutual funds (some index and some actively managed) and 1/3 of my individual account in index funds.

2) Look into a Roth IRA if you plan to hold long term. (For tax purposes). Dividends cause taxable events and are taxed as income, a Roth lets your money grow tax free but you can't take out more than what you originally put in without penalties.

3) Personally I hate the idea of partial shares of stocks/etfs. I'd rather just save up a bit more and buy a full share, but thats just my preference.

As for dividend stocks: CSCO, T, KO, etc. There are many classic dividend stocks you can find on the internet.

author: LuxGang
body:
There's mountains of data that show most people (including professionals who do it for a living) don't beat the market consistently over the long term. If it was so easy to trim the fat, everyone would do it and there would be no market to beat.

The fact that most people lose to the market over the long term is undeniable proof that you will at some point make a mistake, have an emotional reaction, buy too high, or sell too early, and you will lose to the market.

Everyone used to think CSCO, XOM, and T were the future and nothing would stop them. Look where we are now. 

And before you say "BuT tHeSe TeCh CoMpAnIeS aRe DiFfErEnT!" I suggest looking at anti-trust cases of the past, and how those are likely to return with the amount of power these FANG stocks command.

author: AnAnonymousFool
body:
Every stock you mentioned is down 25-40% over the last 5 years. Dividends are great, but you'd have made way more by putting your money into basically any top tech stock

That 13% that GLV pays out is annualized. Per month, they pay out roughly 1%. So essentially you get ~20% total growth over a 5 year period if you account for the decrease in stock price and the lower dividends you get throughout the last 5 years. Compare that to MSFT which is up 340% not including their small 1% dividend. or TSLA which is up 450% over the last 5 years. Or even a less hyped tech stock like Cisco is up 63% in the last 5 years. Or look at some more crazy stocks like Shopify which is up over **2000%** over the last 5 years. Yes you read that right

Dividend stocks are nice to diversify and get some consistent income, but it doesn't have anywhere near the upside that stocks have. To make a livable wage on dividend stocks, you'd have to have somewhere close to a $1M portfolio that is 100% invested into dividend stocks and that would return you like $60k if youre lucky before taxes

Edit: I see I'm getting down votes, so maybe people just hate the tech stock hype, so ill look at other industries. O'Reily Autoparts is up 80% over the past 5 years. McDonalds is up 95% over the last 5 years. The list goes on

Sure there are also some very negative stocks, but dividend stocks will NEVER have the same growth opportunity that a regular stock has

author: kyle_io
body:
It may also be worth looking at this from another angle. You've already shown an interest in some diversification, given your broad accumulation of tech stocks rather than betting on an individual one. And you list an interest in additional companies, 2 payment / financials and 3 healthcare related.

A lot of the focus on long term investing is based on the minimization of downside. Ex: Suppose one company from your list of 7 tech stocks got banned from a country (we're seeing the beginnings of this with Huawei, likely expect some retaliation). How exposed are you to that negative news?

By constructing your own collection of 7+ tech stocks, you'll end up re-creating your own mini diversified ETF. By adding additional sectors into your investment portfolio, you're diversifying your risk from one sector into multiple. The end result is an actively managed portfolio where you do all the work. If you value your time / energy spent on managing stocks in this portfolio, you're effectively paying a fee for this actively managed portfolio. At the very least, you're spending your free time.

Suppose you want to focus on a tech-heavy portfolio, but from a less actively managed standpoint. You can pick up an etf, like VGT for example, that focuses on just the tech sector. From the top asset holdings as of 6/30, that etf holds AAPL, MSFT, V, M, INTC, NVDA, Adobe, Cisco, Paypal, Salesforce with roughly 60% of it's assets. This is actually pretty well aligned with your current collection of stocks. There are individual sector ETFs, dividend growth ETFs, disruptive tech ETFs, and broad market ETFs. It's important to recognize when the collection of stocks you end up with actually aligns with a broader index. Arguably your current portfolio and intended direction seems like 40% VGT and 30% VHT. If later you want to add exposure to other parts of the economy, you might end up with a mix of multiple individual sector ETFs, which might end up having significant overlap with the S&P500 or VTI (total market ETF). A long road to end up at a broad market ETF.

The important thing about ETFs that track benchmarks / indices is that the index is a moving target. Right now there are discussions about TSLA being included in the S&P 500, which would kick some other company out. All the S&P index tracking funds would adjust to this new definition of the index, and all passive investors would then be exposed to TSLA. This is true for many of the index tracking funds, the index definition can change and the funds change to reflect that.

In trying to outperform an index, you're making a bet that you can pick stocks that do better than the continually evolving indices that track economic growth of various sectors. It's always worth evaluating whether you can outperform the 7-9% long term avg the S&P500 returns, and how much effort it takes for you to do that. By spending a lot of time and effort on stocks, you're spending time trying to improve performance on current savings. Your time could also be spent acquiring skills to increase your earning potential, increasing future savings.

TL;DR: Upgrade your portfolio to sector ETFs, eventually to VTI.

author: nascentmind

This is true very much true in India. Most of these "product" companies are heavily filled with contractors and their numbers are almost equal to greater than the permanent employees. There are multiple contractors which are basically outsourcing companies with their employees working onsite at Intel, Cisco etc.

Many a times I see that these contractors are employed to do the death march for failing products or if the company is failing, to keep them afloat. I have seen this with Renesas mobile which had their modem come from Nokia acquisition which had completely failed in the market. They then was brought by Broadcom and everyone was laid off and was again resold to some Chinese company.

author: MementoMori97
body:
Is this for an IRA or Roth IRA or just a normal brokerage account?

Dividends create taxable income so REITs, and other high dividend investments are better suited for a tax-advantaged account. Not that you can't hold them in regular brokerage accounts, you just have taxes to pay on the income.

Personally I think you are too heavily weighted into T, CSCO could be another good tech choice for dividends. Maybe look into a total market index fund or S&P index fund to hold ~1/3 of your portfolio in, this helps mitigate risk and track the market as a whole.

This is just my suggestion, feel free to do what you wish but I enjoy the little volatility saftey net my 30% ITOT holding in my individual account gives me.

author: WrongWeekToQuit
body:
If you look back at the dotcom bubble pop, the one-hit wonders went bankrupt, but their demise also took a lot of wind out of the sails of the big tech names of the day including Microsoft, Cisco, IBM, HP, Sun, INTC, etc.  Yes, some of these were indeed tech companies, but they were huge and some well diversified.  

While NASDAQ dropped around 80% in the recession, even the Russell 2000 dropped about 50% over the same period so everyone took a hit.

author: StoneDragonSD
body: They may very well continue to explode in the short run, but I don’t believe it will last. I think they will come back down to earth. AMZN to me looks like CSCO in 1999. I am not a buyer of tech here.

author: stephenphph
body:
Lots of people dont even know anything about One Stop Systems. Sure it ran up 27% yesterday. But thats nothing for this stock. This could be 50+ in a year or two. Their AI EDGE Technology is superior to competitors and Cloud Technologies and will be used in all AI. They have partnerships with many of the top tech companies and their financials are pretty good. I would wait for a pull back and re-enter. Thats what im doing. Screw these people in here trying to pump a stock for 30 seconds and get out. Unless you have 10k+ and are experienced you should be research good companies you want to invest a little bit into to start, invest, and watch and learn and use some play money to learn with gambling on random stocks you think might take off. If you cant afford to lose money, you need to pick your stocks wisely instead of relying on forums 100%. You need to learn to read charts and learn analysis and market trends etc. Sure you can rely on forums, but 99% of the people here told you not to buy this company and yet they have no idea what they are talking about.

Edit: because im sure some of these pros are going to come out and downvote me and tell me pennies make you rich....

 OSS is partnered with: Apple, NVIDIA, Intel, AMD, Boeing, IBM, Lenovo,  HP, Lyft, Puma, Toshiba, Raytheon, Thunderbolt, Universal Audio,  Focusrite, and Cisco etc...  They also make twice as much revenue as their entire market cap and now  have the only PCIe 4.0 expansion system in the world. 

I can give you an example of EDGE technology vs Cloud technology but honestly all you are looking for is , should i buy? and Im not going to waste my time with that. Research the difference between EDGE technology and Cloud technology... this is how people find these stocks before they blow up. these people in here thinking they are going to get a hot tip everyday on a surefire banger.... absolutely delusional.

author: likeitis121
body:
Eh, I still think it's pretty bad.  We have a whole pile of $10B+ companies that have no expectations of being profitable.  People think dot com bubble was all about these nothing companies, but Cisco, Microsoft, and Intel were some of the big valuation names at the times.  They are all still around, and profitable, but the valuations still can get way off.  Cisco and Intel are still below peaks from 2000, and Microsoft took 16 years to pass it.  

W5000/GDP is about 55% higher than it was in 2000; so unless we think that companies are deriving that much more revenue outside of the country, then I think people are being too complacent about the valuations.

author: Sherpav
body: 7/17 $60 eBay calls, 8/21 $60 CSCO calls, 7/24 $220 MSFT calls, and $130 7/17 WMT calls. I’m pretty stoked with all of them

author: jz187
body:
You got good company. Warren Buffet is buying gas pipelines and Bill Gross is all in on value stocks. I'm buying gas pipelines myself.

Tech is in a bubble. I still remember the dot com bubble of the late 90s. I still remember how Microsoft didn't break even with its 1999 peak until 2015.

If you had invested in a basket of tech stocks back in late 1999, early 2000, chances are, you are only doing well now because of Amazon. Just look at what happened to [Pets.com](https://Pets.com), Cisco, Sun Microsystems, Yahoo, Netscape. Many stocks went to zero, others were bought for pennies on the dollar from their peak valuations. Still others took decades to break even or still hasn't broken even.

The thing is, even with Amazon, you could have bought at 95% off from its bubble peak if you had just waited a few years.

There may very well be a time to buy tech, but that time is not now. The time is when the bubble burst and the valuations are pricing in irrational pessimism. Amazon dropped from $113/share in March 2000 to $5/share in October 2001.

The future of mankind belongs to high tech, but right now there are a lot of posers that are using tech as nothing more than a talking point to scam money from investors. Wait until these guys go bankrupt, and the survivors are priced like they are going out of business, then buy.

In investing, being early is the same thing as being wrong. Many people think tech investing works like early bird gets the worm, but in reality it's the second mouse that gets the cheese. The first wave of investors will fund the build out of all these companies, then there will be a crash as it becomes obvious not all these companies can generate a profit. Then the companies will go bankrupt, consolidate, and the survivors learn how to be profitable. This happened with railroads, cars, aircraft, electronics, internet. Each one was a major tech revolution of its day, and each one also burned a ton of early investors.

The time to buy tech is 2 years after the crash. This gives enough time for the bankruptcies and consolidation to happen.

\---

Oh, and dump Air Canada. Please stay away from Airlines unless you are a better investor than Warren Buffet. Airline investing is not for newbies, it's literally one of the hardest sectors to be a successful investor in. If you scan the world's list of richest people, no one made their money in airlines. If you must, keep 1% at most in AC as play money. Almost no one is smart enough to make money in airlines, you are likely not an exception.

author: MementoMori97
body:
Go with an S&P or total market index fund instead for at least a chunk of your investments to tone down some volatility and uncertainty that individual stocks have.

Personally I stay far far away from WFC in my investments due to their account fraud shit. There are so many better options for individual companies IMO.

The only individual stocks I hold are CSCO, WM, RTX, NOK, BMRG, and PFE.

author: fresh-one
body:
Could be anything. Data collection software, trained models to iterate on with transfer learning, simulation software for generating training data. All of this is time consuming to make. Lyft, Google, Uber all have open sourced some of their data, helping bootstrap something more quickly too. 

They will be behind, sure. But with more resources and scale, one could get ahead eventually too. Look at Huawei-Cisco and 5G. Start from behind but now Huawei is a great choice cost and performance POV.

author: TheTigersAreNotReal
body:
GLW: Glass manufacturer that is used in vials, phones, TVs, and other medical/commercial appliances. They have a contract to produce vials for Pfizer, and received a grant from the government to ensure that they will be able to produce enough vials for the future vaccine. Had their price target upgraded to $33 by Citigroup, currently oversold at $25.75

Don’t know when this thing is gonna moon again, but I hope it’s soon. Probably needs to announce another biomed contract to turn more heads. White knuckling these calls hoping the market realizes its value soon

author: peter-doubt
body:
First: congrats .. good ride!

Second: you beat me in... @70 vs me @140.

Third: we agree .. this price is nuts!  

Percentagewise, your timing has helped you outperform me.  By a long shot!  

What to do next?  I'm looking at SMH.... Semiconductor ETF .. weighted to 5G build out. . oh, NVDA is part of it.

As for dividends.. not much unless you're taking risks with oils, but at 3%, I could suggest Corning (GLW).  Their market volume may be declining, but there's little comment about the volume they can supply to pharma packaging (think billions of doses in glass vials).

Any other ideas?

author: math1024
body:
The main difference between 5G and the previous roll outs is just a lot more fiber and small cell antennas. I think the best 5G plays would be fiber companies like GLW, COMM, and OCC.

There's also been [legislation](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Executive_Order_13858) promoting onshoring so you might want to focus on american manufacturers.

Prudential Financial
